resources.string: If statements are an important part of any useful programming language. They allow the user to determine which blocks of code will run based on certain conditions. An if statement in Python looks like this: if "expression": "statement" \n The expression must resolve to either True or False. If the expression resolves to True, then the proceeding statement will be ran by the program. Otherwise, the program will skip over the statement and continue running. An else statement can be added to end so that a block of code will be run only if all the if statements in the if else block resolve to False.

Here are some common operators used in if expressions: 
 less than < 
 greater than > 
 less than or equal to <= 
 greater than or equal to >= 
 equal to = 
 The "not" operator can be used before an expression to invert the result of the expression.
